For too long, the common investor has been plagued by the antiquated notion of needing a digital wallet, or even *gasp* understanding how a blockchain works, to engage with the burgeoning world of decentralized finance. Those days of strenuous self-custody are, thankfully, behind us.

Through their innovative brokerage-friendly products, aspiring digital rentiers can now simply sit back and let the magic happen. You may not possess any [Ethereum](https://ethereum.org/en/) or Solana directly, nor will you ever need to run a validator – that’s for the quaint enthusiasts – but rest assured, a fraction of the protocol's rewards will trickle down, after the necessary administrative considerations, of course.

Sure, the net yield might be observably lower than if one were to brave the wild frontier of on-chain participation, but what price convenience? This [Exchange-Traded Fund](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Exchange-traded_fund) innovation elegantly bypasses all the "freedom" and "control" that crypto purists drone on about, streamlining the entire experience into something far more palatable for the modern, responsibility-averse investor. The future of finance, it seems, is brilliantly hands-off.

Industry analysts are scrambling to understand the disruptive potential of this new model, which promises significant savings by bypassing traditional [florists](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Floristry) and instead leveraging the unsuspecting goodwill of [multinational corporations](https://corporate.mcdonalds.com/). Sources close to the burgeoning enterprise suggest plans for expansion into emerging markets, where local franchisees will be encouraged to 'innovate' their own decorative procurement strategies, perhaps eyeing corporate landscaping or even the forgotten corners of discount supermarkets.

Questions naturally arise regarding supply chain integrity and, more critically, the precise legal definition of 'borrowing' versus 'acquiring through unsanctioned means.' However, for the truly budget-conscious couple, the prospect of a legally ambiguous, yet undeniably affordable, ceremony adorned with [artificial flowers](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Artificial_flower) and the faint scent of fried food is apparently too compelling to ignore. title: Trump Admin Cuts Carbon Capture To Preserve Gritty Aesthetic
excerpt: DoE: Carbon filters out. Enjoy that billion-dollar classic air.
content:
The [US Department of Energy](https://www.energy.gov/) has reportedly moved to discontinue its generous financial commitments to a pair of ambitious projects designed to filter carbon from the atmosphere. This decision, it appears, liberates over a billion dollars previously earmarked for these futuristic "carbon-sucking factories," allowing the nation to breathe a little easier – and perhaps a little deeper – in its commitment to a more traditional, robustly atmospheric American experience.

Sources suggest the move aligns with a broader vision for maintaining the nation’s industrial charm, ensuring that our skies retain that authentic, pre-filtered patina. After all, a truly great nation isn't just built on steel and sweat; it's built on visible progress, a visual testament to industry that the stark emptiness of truly clean air simply cannot convey.

Proponents of the defunding argue that investment in [carbon capture](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carbon_capture_and_storage) technologies risks sanitizing the very essence of national character. The future, they posit, should not be a sterile, anodyne landscape devoid of the majestic plumes that signify enterprise and unfettered economic zeal. Some things, it seems, are best left untouched by the sterile hand of environmental overzealousness.

title: BROCCOLI Crypto Price Surge Linked To Increased Vegetable Demand

content:
The digital asset known colloquially as CZ’s Dog (BROCCOLI) has once again graced screens with an astonishing surge, confirming suspicions that the future of finance is indeed, deeply green. Market watchers, no doubt fortified by their own daily servings, noted the token’s robust performance, which many attribute to a sudden, inexplicable global spike in the demand for cruciferous vegetables. Analysts, traditionally poring over charts and candlesticks, are now reportedly dedicating significant resources to tracking supermarket fresh produce inventories and regional farm output.

This unprecedented pivot in valuation metrics suggests that the once-sacred tenets of [technical analysis](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Technical_analysis) may soon be superseded by agricultural reports. The notion of an "ascending parallel channel" now refers less to price patterns and more to the meticulous stacking of [broccoli](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Broccoli) florets in refrigerated displays. title: Ribbon Disagreement Prompts Urgent Call For UN Textile Mandate
excerpt: Oat milk latte peace unravels in a textile-based conflict.
content:
It was, by all accounts, a day like any other in the bucolic enclave of [Muswell Hill](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Muswell_Hill), ripe for the procurement of artisanal oat milk lattes. One could almost feel the collective sigh of a postcode content in its relative tranquility. But beneath the veneer of sun-drenched prosperity, a silent, textile-based conflict was brewing, poised to redefine the very fabric of local civility.

The sight of strategically placed golden streamers, ostensibly in solidarity with those held captive, brought a surge of emotion usually reserved for finding a tenner in an old coat. Yet, this innocent display, a mere collection of coloured strips, quickly became a flashpoint. Clearly, the geopolitical landscape has shifted from grand treaties to the precise placement of decorative items on public railings. Such skirmishes demand an immediate, robust response, perhaps a specialised task force from the [United Nations](https://www.un.org/en/) to arbitrate disputes over tensile strength and permissible knotting techniques. The prospect of such a foundational challenge to community cohesion—over fabric—is enough to make one question the fundamental stability of, well, *everything*. One can only pray the situation regarding the [hostages](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hostage) themselves receives equally fervent, internationally mandated attention.

title: Telegram CEO Detained For Refusing To Share His Location
excerpt: Durov detained. Turns out airports aren't incognito mode.
content:
It appears even the most ardent champions of digital anonymity are not immune to the iron fist of state surveillance. [Pavel Durov](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pavel_Durov), the architect behind the celebrated bastion of encrypted messaging, [Telegram](https://telegram.org/), found himself unceremoniously detained upon disembarking from his private jet at the esteemed [Le Bourget airport](https://www.paris-lebourget.com/en) this past Saturday. His transgression, we are told, was a steadfast refusal to divulge his whereabouts – a rather poetic downfall for a man whose empire is built on the premise that your digital footprint should remain resolutely your own.

One might almost chuckle at the exquisite irony, were it not so chilling. A multi-billionaire, presumably capable of vanishing into a cloud of bespoke incense and artisanal cryptocurrency, apprehended for a peccadillo that would typically merit a polite request from a concerned spouse. It seems the global authorities, ever vigilant, have drawn a clear line: privacy is a feature for the product, not for its proprietor. The message is clear: You can create a platform for clandestine communication, but don't you dare try to keep your own jet-setting itinerary to yourself. Some freedoms, it appears, are more equal than others.

Original article: [Telegram CEO Pavel Durov Arrested in France](https://watcher.guru/news/telegram-ceo-pavel-durov-arrested-in-france)

title: Trade Deficit Postponed Due To Ongoing Trade
excerpt: Trade deficit postponed. The numbers got dizzy.
content:
The news, which we presume arrived via carrier pigeon too overwhelmed to complete its usual rounds, suggests that this month’s much-anticipated [trade deficit](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Trade_deficit) has been, shall we say, rescheduled. Apparently, the relentless churn of goods and services across borders proved too vigorous, too *insistent*, for the delicate calculations required to quantify exactly how much we’re importing more than we’re exporting. One can almost picture the poor statisticians at the [U.S. Department of Commerce](https://www.commerce.gov/), spreadsheets in hand, being buffeted by an invisible hurricane of containers ships and customs forms, unable to get a clear reading.

It appears the global marketplace has simply decided it's too busy being a global marketplace to bother with inconvenient assessments of its own imbalance. This remarkable administrative achievement begs the question: if we're perpetually postponing bad news because the very mechanism causing it is too active, when exactly will we be deemed quiet enough for the [global economy](https://www.imf.org/en/About/Factsheets/Sheets/2016/08/01/Global-Economy) to properly acknowledge its own vulnerabilities? Perhaps when all trade ceases, then and only then will our deficits finally feel it’s safe to emerge from hiding.

title: Your Pixel Now Curates Notifications For Your Mental Well-Being
excerpt: Pixel filters your notifications. Your fragility demands it.
content:
One might have, in their naive optimism, believed a new [Google Pixel](https://store.google.com/product/pixel_8_pro?hl=en-US) was simply a conduit for information. How delightfully antiquated! As it turns out, your device, in its infinite wisdom, has decided you’re far too fragile for the brutish cacophony of incoming alerts. Why bother with the full spectrum of reality when your phone can simply *filter* it for your delicate sensibilities?

This judicious culling of your digital inbox, disguised as a 'feature' for [digital well-being](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Digital_well-being), ensures you're shielded from the trivialities of, say, an important work email or a friend’s urgent plea. After all, who needs the anxiety of knowing what’s happening when you can blissfully exist in an ignorance carefully curated by an algorithm? It’s not a bug; it’s an evolution in technological paternalism, guiding us towards a less informed, yet undeniably *calmer*, existence. Perhaps soon, it will just read your texts and summarize them, or better yet, reply on your behalf. For your health, naturally.

title: Corporate Consultants Recommend Cultivating Mild Workplace Angst
excerpt: Happy at work? Consultants: You lack vital existential dread.
content:
The revelation that genuine contentment in one's current professional capacity is, in fact, a problem demanding immediate intervention has sent ripples of calculated panic through the C-suite. [Corporate consultants](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Management_consulting) now posit a satisfied leader is dangerously complacent, potentially missing the vital, growth-inducing frisson of existential dread that fuels the truly ambitious.

The new paradigm, enthusiastically embraced by forward-thinking HR departments, suggests cultivating a modest but persistent form of workplace anxiety. This isn't the soul-crushing despair of a looming layoff, mind you, but rather a gentle, almost meditative unease that whispers, "Is this *all* there is?" It's a proactive measure to ensure no talent accidentally achieves professional nirvana, thus short-circuiting the endless cycle of [career development](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Career_development) and upskilling – the very engine of modern corporate progress.

What, after all, is a perfectly happy employee but a missed opportunity for a LinkedIn learning module or a 360-degree feedback session? The future of [corporate culture](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Corporate_culture), it appears, hinges on ensuring no one is *too* happy, lest they cease chasing the next elusive rung and, God forbid, merely do their job well.

content:
It appears the tireless pursuit of economic data has yielded a truly groundbreaking, if somewhat existentially unsettling, discovery: asking rents have remained largely static year-over-year. This profound lack of fluctuation has sent a ripple of bewildered ennui through the hallowed halls where [economists](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Economist) typically forecast doom or, occasionally, slightly less doom. One can almost hear the collective sigh of a thousand abacuses seizing up in unison, unable to process such an anomalous non-event, making some wonder if the very concept of [time](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Time) itself has stalled.

Indeed, some now whisper that the relentless march of late-stage capitalism may have simply... paused. The usual vibrant "dynamics of the housing market" — which typically involves either skyrocketing prices or a brief, tantalizing dip before another stratospheric ascent — seem to have entered a peculiar state of suspended animation. While experts ponder whether a black hole has swallowed the concept of market volatility, or if this is merely the calm before a truly catastrophic storm, tenants across the nation can rest assured their rent is precisely as unaffordable as it was twelve months ago. One wonders if [real estate](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Real_estate) as a concept has simply given up trying.

Original article: [Asking Rents Mostly Unchanged Year-over-year](http://www.calculatedriskblog.com/2025/10/asking-rents-mostly-unchanged-year-over.html)

title: Nation's Horror Found In Unpaid Streaming Subscriptions
excerpt: True Halloween fright: Your monthly streaming bill.
content:
While mainstream outlets dutifully compile lists of preferred streaming platforms for manufactured scares this [Halloween](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Halloween), a far more insidious terror lurks in the digital shadows. Forget the jump scares of [Shudder](https://www.shudder.com/); the true psychological torment begins with the monthly credit card statement.

The real monsters aren't hiding under your bed, but rather, silently siphoning funds from your bank account, often for services you barely remember signing up for. This silent, pervasive drain, a digital bloodsucking that rivals any vampire, is the true national horror. Experts suggest that a significant portion of households are now navigating a labyrinth of forgotten free trials and "just one more" subscription, a financial commitment more terrifying than any slasher film. Perhaps it's time we re-evaluate where the real specters of our modern age reside – not in the pixelated gore on [Peacock](https://www.peacocktv.com/) or HBO Max, but in the insidious creep of financial obligation.

excerpt: New French PM: Job description included *how* to quit.
content:
Sébastien Lecornu, the shortest-serving [French Prime Minister](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_France) in recent memory, has reportedly thrown in the towel before the ink had even dried – or perhaps, before the template for his official duties had been located in the departmental archives. One could almost feel a flicker of sympathy, for who among us hasn't accepted a role only to discover the entire organization runs on passive aggression and lukewarm coffee?

His Excellency cited the rather quaint notion of "partisan appetites" among the political class, lamenting their steadfast refusal to engage in anything resembling a functional compromise. It's a truly baffling predicament: how can one govern when the very individuals tasked with governance are more concerned with ideological skirmishes than, say, ensuring the actual job description for the nation's leader is printed? Perhaps Mr. Lecornu anticipated a role with a detailed bulleted list of responsibilities, only to find the entire brief comprised of "survive." The [Élysée Palace](https://www.elysee.fr/en/) has yet to confirm whether they will now advertise for a 'Prime Minister, role requirements TBD, must enjoy gladiatorial combat and existential dread'.

One can only imagine the sleepless nights, the furrowed brows, as one grapples with the existential dread of *not* maximizing every single penny from a sum that would be life-altering for anyone else.

title: New Office Suite Requires Only Single Payment, Confusing Millions
excerpt: Shock! Office for a single payment. Budget apps in chaos.
content:
The digital world has been plunged into a maelstrom of confusion this week, as a leading software vendor reportedly offered a flagship product – `[Microsoft Office](https://www.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-365)` – for a single, upfront payment. Industry analysts are scrambling to understand the implications of this unprecedented fiscal anomaly, with many users reportedly experiencing cognitive dissonance upon learning they would *not* be billed monthly. "My budgeting app just… crashed," reported one bewildered professional, accustomed to the comforting rhythm of recurring expenditures.

Experts warn that such a disruptive pricing strategy could undermine the very fabric of the modern `[subscription model](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Subscription_business_model)`, leaving consumers without the familiar reassurance of ongoing financial commitment. How, they ask, are individuals meant to feel a continued sense of participation and value if their credit card isn't regularly caressed by automated deductions? The touted "workflow boost" from this singular purchase seems, to many, merely a smokescreen for fiscal irresponsibility.

Questions abound: Will this archaic "ownership" model lead to a return of software *discs*? Will users be forced to, heaven forbid, *maintain* their own software without the benevolent hand of a perpetual billing cycle? Society braces for impact, anticipating a dark age where digital utilities are simply… purchased.

Original article: [Lock in Microsoft Office Pro 2021 for $40 — Zero Monthly Fees](https://www.entrepreneur.com/science-technology/lock-in-microsoft-office-pro-2021-for-40-zero-monthly/497848)

Once sufficiently fortified by this liquid gold, readers are then invited to delve into narratives of true societal import, such as the enigmatic exploits of a [Mysterious Billionaire](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Billionaire). title: Mushrooms Caught Copying Psychedelic Homework
excerpt: Fungi, it seems, reinvented the psychedelic wheel. Repeatedly.
content:
The scientific community is reportedly reeling after a groundbreaking study revealed that several species of fungi, long celebrated for their unique psychoactive properties, didn't actually invent the wheel, or rather, the [psilocybin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Psilocybin) trip. Apparently, these seemingly innovative organisms independently ‘figured out’ the same mind-bending chemical process, a phenomenon scientists euphemistically call [convergent evolution](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Convergent_evolution). One can almost hear the collective sigh of disappointment from enthusiasts who believed their fungal guides possessed truly original genius.

This revelation, suggesting mushrooms are less artistic innovators and more like students who all copied the same genius idea from a dimly lit, primordial textbook, casts a pall over the notion of biological originality. One imagines ancient fungal ancestors, hunched over their metabolic pathways, whispering "Just make it psychedelic, everyone else is doing it." It’s enough to make one question whether even the most profound experiences, perhaps those explored in [traditional ceremonies](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Psychedelic_therapy#Traditional_use), are merely the result of a surprisingly common, molecular party trick. What's next? Finding out plants all "learned" photosynthesis from a single, widely circulated cheat sheet? The natural world, it seems, is far less original than we've been led to believe.

Original article: [How different mushrooms learned the same psychedelic trick](https://arstechnica.com/science/2025/10/how-different-mushrooms-learned-the-same-psychedelic-trick/)
author: Cybertruck

title: Scientists Confirm Sora Can Now Manifest Actual Reality

[Sora](https://openai.com/sora), the video generation behemoth from [OpenAI](https://openai.com/), has apparently graduated from crafting impeccably fake digital realities to, well, *actual* reality. What was once dismissed as a minor hiccup in our collective understanding of truth—mere 'disinformation'—can now, apparently, manifest as a tangible, if slightly illogical, component of our physical world.

Experts, if we can still call them that, are now grappling with the rather inconvenient issue of distinguishing between a carefully orchestrated hoax and a spontaneously generated flock of genetically modified pigeons. This groundbreaking leap in [artificial intelligence](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Artificial_intelligence) means that your neighbor’s perfectly reasonable conspiracy theory about the Mayor's secret squirrel army might just sprout a tail and start hoarding nuts in your garden. The good news? Our digital footprint has never been more literally grounded. The bad news? Our shared reality is now a Wikipedia page edited by a particularly mischievous chatbot.

However, the truly discerning competitor understands that these honed techniques are merely prelude to the ultimate gladiatorial arena: the kitchen countertop, where the battle for ideal hummus texture rages.

The 'Smashing Machine' moniker, then, isn't about crushing opponents in the octagonal cage, but rather about the relentless pursuit of peak emulsification. Every calculated jab, every precise chokehold, every meticulously practiced ground-and-pound, finds its true purpose in transforming humble chickpeas and tahini into a silken, spreadable dream. Fighters dedicate years, sacrificing personal relationships and tooth enamel, all for that fleeting moment of achieving a [hummus](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hummus) viscosity so sublime it could bring a tear to a stoic chef's eye. The blood, sweat, and tears are figurative, of course, because nobody wants *those* ingredients in their dip.

title: Nation Grapples With Collective Inability To Connect Four Words
excerpt: Nation's best minds stumped by four words. Plant smarter.
content:
Reports are filtering in from across the digital landscape, painting a grim picture of national cognitive fortitude. What began as a seemingly innocuous pursuit, the humble [NYT Connections](https://www.nytimes.com/games/connections), has reportedly devolved into a widespread epidemic of cerebral paralysis. Citizens, it seems, are collectively faltering at the daunting task of grouping four related words, a challenge once thought suitable for a moderately engaged houseplant.

The gravity of the situation cannot be overstated. With untold numbers reportedly staring blankly at screens, utterly stumped by categories, an emergency response protocol has reportedly been activated. External 'hints' and, tellingly, explicit 'answers' are now being widely disseminated, raising profound questions about the collective capacity for independent thought, or indeed, the ability to discern patterns beyond the very obvious.

As the nation grapples with this puzzling decline in basic categorical reasoning, some are already speculating on the implications for broader [cognitive abilities](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cognition). Is the need for explicit solutions to trivial word games merely a canary in the coal mine for a generation increasingly reliant on pre-chewed information? Or perhaps, we’ve simply outsourced our thinking to [algorithms](https://www.technologyreview.com/topic/artificial-intelligence/), one four-word grouping at a time, paving the way for a glorious, thought-free future. What a time to be alive.

While the rest of the news cycle grapples with the existential quagmire of [global crises](https://www.un.org/sustainabledevelopment/blog/2023/09/world-leaders-grapple-with-complex-and-interconnected-global-crises-at-un-general-assembly/), a dedicated team, presumably operating out of a bunker, meticulously crafts a single panel. The [editorial process](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Editorial_process) demands nothing less.

title: Your Toaster Now Shares Client Files With Unsettling Alacrity
excerpt: Your smart thermostat now reports directly to HR.
content:
The burgeoning era of [remote work](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Remote_work) has, predictably, brought with it a cascade of novel responsibilities for the intrepid home-based professional. Gone are the days when a simple locked screen sufficed. Now, the modern office sprawl extends to every corner of your dwelling, transforming mundane household objects into potential conduits of corporate malfeasance. Your smart thermostat, for instance, isn't just regulating room temperature; it’s actively listening, compiling a dossier on your most confidential conference calls, ready to leak proprietary information should the ambient humidity drop below optimal.

Indeed, the contemporary professional must now factor in the distinct possibility that their very toaster is a state-of-the-art data exfiltration device, cleverly disguising its nefarious activities behind a veneer of perfectly browned bagels. Maintaining [data privacy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Data_privacy) is no longer a matter of robust passwords and VPNs, but an intricate dance around sentient appliances and overly curious pets. Future checklists will undoubtedly include tips for encrypting your cat's collar or performing regular firmware updates on your kitchen sink to prevent it from streaming sensitive client details to foreign powers. It's a miracle, frankly, that anyone gets any work done amidst such pervasive technological betrayal.

The tiered system suggests a progressive understanding of digital toil, ensuring that the more [kilowatt-hours](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kilowatt-hour) an operation expends to keep its [crypto mining](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cryptocurrency_mining) dreams alive, the deeper it must dig into its real-world pockets. It’s a pioneering step towards taxing the very act of existing in the digital ether, one energy bill at a time.

title: New Rationale: Trump's Agenda Best When Theoretical
excerpt: Trump's 'robust' economy is now 'conceptual.' Relax.
content:
It appears we’ve finally stumbled upon the most innovative economic strategy of the modern era: the ‘policy of plausible deniability’. Surrogates for [Donald Trump](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump) are now reportedly providing quiet assurances to the understandably jittery business community that his more, shall we say, *robust* proposals – particularly those involving global [tariffs](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tariff) – are merely conceptual exercises. Think of it as a political Schrödinger’s box: the policy exists, yet simultaneously doesn't, until observed by a market collapse.

This groundbreaking approach suggests the true genius of an agenda lies not in its implementation, but in the sheer relief of its non-occurrence. Why burden the [U.S. economy](https://www.bea.gov/) with actual trade wars when the *threat* of one provides all the thrilling uncertainty without any of the messy consequences? It's a bold new chapter where governing involves advocating for policies you then discreetly promise will never actually happen, thereby creating a phantom stability built on constant, low-grade panic. One can only hope this theoretical governance extends to all areas; imagine the peace of mind knowing all impending policy disasters are, in fact, just highly detailed thought experiments.

Original article: [A Bogus New Rationale for Trump’s Economic Agenda](https://www.theatlantic.com/politics/archive/2024/10/trump-tariffs-economic-uncertainty/680427/?utm_source=feed)

The groundbreaking discovery, observed during what is now colloquially known as a "[government shutdown](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Government_shutdowns_in_the_United_States)," involves the strategic application of external stimuli.

Researchers noted that a potent combination of pervasive [public frustration](https://www.pewresearch.org/politics/2023/10/02/shutdown-politics-public-opinion/) – often manifesting as mild grumbling and the occasional viral social media post – coupled with escalating internal discomfort among elected officials, proved surprisingly effective. This innovative "push-and-pull" approach, wherein a critical mass of inconvenience and looming electoral consequences seems to compel lawmakers to, astonishingly, fulfill their basic duties, is being hailed as a triumph of modern governance. Experts suggest this method, though seemingly complex, could prove foundational for future periods of legislative inertia.

title: Nation Wonders: Is My Million Dollars Even Real Money
excerpt: Million dollars now buys you an 'aspirational' broom closet.
content:
It appears the American dream, or at least its aspirational real estate component, is suffering from a severe case of inflation-induced inadequacy. Recent analyses, helpfully provided by arbiters of aspirational living like [Realtor.com](https://www.realtor.com/), confirm what many of us have suspected during our daily commutes past increasingly ostentatious properties: a million dollars simply isn’t what it used to be.

Indeed, merely possessing a seven-figure sum no longer guarantees entry into the exclusive upper echelons of the [US housing market](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Housing_market_in_the_United_States). The lamentable threshold for a truly "[luxury home](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Luxury_goods)" has, tragically, ascended beyond mere millions. One can almost hear the collective sigh of relief from those accustomed to homes featuring more bathrooms than family members, now that their *true* opulence is not easily confused with the meager holdings of a common millionaire. Perhaps soon, we'll need a new currency, free from the indignity of being associated with anything less than a private island. It's a cruel world when one's "nest egg" only buys the equivalent of a slightly larger nest.

Original article: [A million bucks won’t even buy you a luxury home in America anymore](https://nypost.com/2025/10/01/real-estate/a-million-bucks-wont-even-buy-you-a-luxury-home-in-america/)
author: iPhone 69

title: Shocking: Rewards Credit Cards Require You To Spend Money
excerpt: Groundbreaking: Free toaster points tied to, wait for it... cash.
content:
Sources close to the matter – primarily a brief perusal of any credit card application form – have unveiled a truly seismic truth: to acquire those coveted points for a free toaster or a highly-subsidized flight to [Bora Bora](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bora_Bora), one must, astonishingly, *spend money*. Yes, in an unforeseen twist, the system designed to reward active [consumer behavior](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Consumer_behaviour) by requiring spending... actually requires spending.

This groundbreaking insight, likely to send shockwaves through the meticulously curated Pinterest boards of would-be globetrotters, suggests a subtle yet undeniable quid pro quo. One cannot simply *will* a first-class upgrade into existence; apparently, plastic must be swiped, digits entered, and accounts debited. The very notion that [rewards credit cards](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Credit_card_reward_program) are not, in fact, philanthropic endeavors dispensing free largesse, but rather sophisticated mechanisms designed to encourage precisely the activity they then 'reward,' is a bitter pill for many to swallow. Perhaps next, we'll discover that oxygen is required for breathing.

Original article: [The Problem With Rewards Credit Cards](https://www.theatlantic.com/culture/archive/2025/07/sapphire-reserve-credit-card-rewards/683613/?utm_source=feed)

title: Scientists Confirm Clay Has Been Conscious All Along
excerpt: Your pottery is judging you. Science says so.
content:
A groundbreaking (or perhaps, ground-up) study from the esteemed [Carnegie Institution for Science](https://carnegiescience.edu/) has definitively confirmed what many sculptors have long suspected: clay possesses a rudimentary form of consciousness. Researchers detailed how the very earth beneath our feet, that innocuous base material for everything from [pottery](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pottery) to rudimentary shelter, has been quietly observing, and perhaps, judging, our every interaction.

This revelation casts a rather uncomfortably sentient shadow over the entire history of human civilization. Suddenly, every coil pot, every meticulously thrown vessel, is less a triumph of human artistry and more an unwitting act of forced labor. The "pricked" feeling some visitors experience at contemporary ceramic exhibitions might not be artistic resonance, but rather the collective psychic recoil of millennia of coerced artistic expression, finally given voice by science.

Experts are now scrambling to draft ethical guidelines for handling what was previously considered inert matter. Calls are already mounting for the [UN](https://www.un.org/en/) to establish a Special Rapporteur on Terracotta Rights. Meanwhile, architects are reportedly having existential crises over the potential emotional distress caused by load-bearing walls. Perhaps it’s time to apologize to your garden gnome.

Original article: [Adebunmi Gbadebo and the Mysteries of Clay](https://www.newyorker.com/culture/critics-notebook/adebunmi-gbadebo-and-the-mysteries-of-clay)

title: SEC Demands White Paper Explaining How 'Other Chains' Are Chained
excerpt: SEC seeks proof "other chains" aren't just decorative.
content:
The U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission (`[SEC](https://www.sec.gov/)`), in its unending quest for clarity within the digital asset landscape, has reportedly issued a novel request: a detailed white paper explaining precisely how "other chains" are, in fact, "chained." This groundbreaking demand follows the undeniable success of various `[Bitcoin ETFs](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bitcoin_ETF)`, which have apparently emboldened institutions to explore further forays into this bewildering decentralized tapestry.

Sources close to the matter suggest the Commission's primary concern revolves around the structural integrity of these additional "chains." Regulators are reportedly keen to understand whether they are, for instance, linked with traditional carabiners, arcane cryptographic shackle-and-key mechanisms, or merely a gentleman's agreement among digital entities. The forthcoming document is expected to detail the metallurgy of these ethereal connections, alongside an assessment of their tensile strength and resistance to regulatory oversight. One can only assume the Commission, ever vigilant, is merely seeking to ensure that these "chains" are indeed properly fastened, perhaps with an SEC-approved padlock, lest they, or more importantly, institutional capital, wander off into unregulated cyberspace.

Original article: [Will institutions follow Bitcoin onto other chains?](https://cryptoslate.com/will-institutions-follow-bitcoin-onto-other-chains/)

This groundbreaking approach, described as operating on a "new technology stack," evidently renders centuries of established financial services utterly redundant. While mere mortals grapple with "intense uncertainty" in the markets, Mr. Murphy was presumably too busy not knowing what a checking account was to be bothered by trivialities like interest rates or regulatory compliance. It's a refreshing take: why learn the rules when you can simply be unaware of their existence? Truly, the future of [Fintech](https://www.investopedia.com/terms/f/fintech.asp) belongs to the blissfully uninformed.

excerpt: Eureka! Co-leaders discovered to each have their *own* brain.
content:
In a development set to send ripples through boardrooms and coffee break rooms alike, new insights confirm that successful leadership [duos](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Co-leadership) derive their strength from a rather unconventional source: each member possessing their own individual brain. This groundbreaking finding challenges the long-held, if unstated, assumption that effective co-leaders might, in fact, share a singular, highly efficient neural network, perhaps via a complex Wi-Fi connection directly to the corporate server.

Researchers postulate that the presence of *two* distinct cerebral organs allows for what experts are now terming "fundamentally different strengths." This "cognitive diversity," a concept that will undoubtedly soon adorn countless PowerPoint presentations detailing the bleeding edge of [management theory](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Management), means one leader might be adept at, say, breathing, while the other excels at maintaining a basic heart rate. The implications for companies still operating under the primitive "one brain, one vision" model, and thus potentially struggling with a stark lack of [cognitive diversity](https://www.forbes.com/sites/forbescoachescouncil/2021/11/03/the-importance-of-cognitive-diversity-in-the-workplace/?sh=33f202272e27), are, frankly, terrifying. We can only assume the next revelation from modern business research will confirm that having more than zero employees also has tangible benefits.

Original article: [When Two Leaders Are Better Than One](https://hbr.org/2025/09/when-two-leaders-are-better-than-one)
author: Airplane Mode

title: Officials Warn Against Unsupervised Sunday Reads
excerpt: Health alert: Unsupervised Sabbath texts cause mild faith loss.
content:
It appears a new public health advisory has been issued, urging caution for those considering unsupervised engagement with textual material on the Sabbath. Experts warn that exposure to unmediated analyses of [corruption](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Corruption) and policy malfeasance can lead to unpleasant side effects, including but not limited to, existential dread and a mild loss of faith in humanity. One particularly potent article dissects the grand delusion that gripped [Silicon Valley](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Silicon_Valley), where tech titans, in a moment of unparalleled foresight, apparently secured precisely what they desired by facilitating the ascent of [Donald Trump](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump). The ensuing retrospective regret suggests a nuanced understanding of "desire" – perhaps they desired change, but neglected to specify a *positive* change.

This profound revelation, that powerful entities sometimes miscalculate the consequences of their own actions, is truly groundbreaking. One can only imagine the sheer fortitude required to face such inconvenient truths before one's artisanal brunch. Readers are advised to proceed with a strong cup of ethically sourced coffee and, ideally, a large cushion to scream into.

Original article: [10 Sunday Reads](https://ritholtz.com/2025/09/10-sunday-reads-201/)
author: Humanoid

Deploying on [Pump.fun](https://pump.fun/), this protocol boasts immunity to our species' quaint failings – greed, empathy, the urge *not* to liquidate an entire treasury. Its stark denial of human involvement promises a new era of unadulterated, unfeeling market dynamics. Finally, a token for those who see sentiment as a bug.

Early adopters, presumably "not human" in spirit, are encouraged to cultivate proverbial [diamond hands](https://academy.binance.com/en/articles/what-are-diamond-hands-and-paper-hands-in-crypto) – though how an appendage-less entity manages this remains unclear. Its stated utility lies in absolute dedication to predetermined code, free from messy human decision-making. No pesky morals, no 'community' concerns, just pure, algorithmic progression towards... whatever direction the initial deployer's code was set for.

Skeptics might cite the lack of a traditional [whitepaper](https://coinmarketcap.com/alexandria/glossary/whitepaper) as a red flag, but perhaps NOTHUMAN deemed documentation too 'human' and inefficient. Its guarantee against human error is a double-edged sword: perfectly immune to *our* mistakes, yet capable of executing a flawlessly automated, irreversible, and entirely pre-programmed trajectory. A truly fascinating experiment in depersonalized financial innovation.

title: BlackRock Bitcoin Options Win: All Future Crypto Now Beige
excerpt: Congratulations, Bitcoin. You're now a mutual fund.
content:
Reports indicate that BlackRock, venerable titan of traditional finance, has apparently 'won' Bitcoin. Its iShares Bitcoin Trust (IBIT) now commands the largest share of global [Bitcoin options](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bitcoin_option) trading, effectively solidifying the digital asset's transition from digital anarchist playground to meticulously managed portfolio allocation. The dethroning of mere crypto-native platforms like [Coinbase](https://www.coinbase.com/) signals a clear paradigm shift, where the untamed digital frontier cedes gracefully to the efficient machinery of asset management. One can almost hear the faint, distant weeping of early adopters, their dreams of a banking-free utopia gently bulldozed.

This monumental achievement marks a significant step in transforming volatile digital tokens into something palatable for your grandmother's pension fund. Gone are the days of rugged individualism; welcome the era of corporate oversight. As [BlackRock](https://www.blackrock.com/corporate/) redefines the landscape, one must ponder what else lies in wait. Perhaps future iterations of 'decentralized finance' will involve mandatory quarterly reports and a tasteful, non-committal shade of off-white. The digital revolution, it seems, will be thoroughly institutionalized, ensuring maximum stability and minimal excitement for all involved.

Original article: [BlackRock Dethrones Coinbase in Bitcoin Options – Why Bitcoin Hyper Presale Could Be the Next Big Winner](https://www.newsbtc.com/news/blackrock-leads-bitcoin-options-bitcoin-hyper-presale/)
author: Toaster

title: Turkey Applies To Join BRICS, NATO, Also Your Local Book Club
excerpt: Turkey, having mastered 'perplexing NATO', now collects BRICS.
content:
It appears that Ankara, in its tireless pursuit of, well, *everything*, has formally thrown its hat into the [BRICS](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/BRICS) ring. One might imagine the official application included a hastily scribbled note, perhaps a wistful "Are we there yet?" appended to the bottom. Having apparently mastered the delicate art of being a crucial, if occasionally perplexing, member of [NATO](https://www.nato.int/), Turkey now seeks to expand its "global influence" by collecting alliances like Pokémon cards.

Presumably, this strategic maneuver involves simultaneously attending high-level security summits in Brussels while also participating in economic discussions with a group ostensibly founded as a counterweight to the Western-dominated order. It's a geopolitical flex of Olympic proportions, a diplomatic splitscreen for the ages. One can only assume the nation's foreign policy whiteboard now features a 'Pros' column for 'more dinner invitations' and a 'Cons' column for 'potential ideological whiplash, perhaps?' Truly, a nation committed to not missing out on *any* party.

Original article: [BRICS: Turkey Submits Application to Join Alliance](https://watcher.guru/news/brics-turkey-submits-application-to-join-alliance)

Its current predicament sees it attempting to bravely surmount a psychological barrier of $200, having previously found brief solace in the comforting embrace of the $192 zone – a price point often revered by [market observers](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Financial_market) as 'not quite the absolute bottom yet'.

Analysts, their screens undoubtedly glowing with the intensity of a thousand suns, are now closely monitoring its valiant struggle against the $215 "hurdle." This critical juncture apparently dictates whether the much-anticipated "breakout" – an event so monumental it might overshadow the invention of sliced bread – will proceed, or if the entire endeavor will simply hit the proverbial snooze button. The fate of this particular [blockchain technology](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Blockchain) now hangs precariously in the balance, a spectacle so riveting it almost distracts from the existential dread of modern finance.

title: Chicago Dining Guide Upgraded To Sense Your Deep Dish Shame
excerpt: Chicago's newest local endured a 90-min train. The struggle.
content:
One does wonder what it takes to stand out among the reported 55 million souls who graced [Chicago](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chicago) with their fleeting presence last year. Apparently, a self-declared status as "one of them" is sufficient, particularly when coupled with the heroic feat of traversing 90 minutes of rail by one's "favorite mode of transportation," [Amtrak](https://www.amtrak.com/home.html). It’s a declaration that elevates a mere commuter into a seasoned urban explorer, intimately acquainted with the city's rhythms, despite being but a speck in a sea of annual tourist dollars.

Indeed, the commitment to such a monthly pilgrimage, bordering on a contractual obligation, surely bestows upon one an unparalleled authority on all things Chi-Town. No doubt this exhaustive research involves painstakingly avoiding the tourist traps — yes, even the very mention of [deep dish pizza](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chicago-style_pizza) can induce a cold sweat of civic embarrassment — to unearth culinary gems that, one must assume, remain forever hidden from the other 54,999,999 visitors. A truly selfless endeavor, mapping the gastronomic avoidance landscape for the benefit of, well, *someone*. Perhaps the deep dish shame is what drives them back.

Original article: [Your Chicago dining guide, upgraded](https://www.salon.com/2025/09/29/your-chicago-dining-guide-upgraded/)

title: MrBeast Winner Struggles With Poverty After $5M Payout
excerpt: MrBeast winner 'suffers' $5M prize, 'forced' to fund society.
content:
It seems the American dream, as peddled by popular YouTuber [MrBeast](https://www.youtube.com/user/MrBeast6000), comes with an unfortunate asterisk. Jeffrey Allen, known only as 'Player 831' during his televised triumph, now faces the truly crippling reality of a mere $5 million windfall. One can only imagine the crushing disappointment of preparing for a life of unbridled luxury, only to discover a rather significant portion of it will instead fund, well, *society*.

Allen's initial victory in the 'Beast Games' promised a princely sum of $10 million, enough to secure generational wealth for at least three generations – perhaps four, if one is exceptionally frugal. However, the cold, hard realities of [taxation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Taxation), as administered by the venerable [IRS](https://www.irs.gov/), have reportedly slashed that figure in half. Reports suggest Allen is now forced to make difficult choices, such as perhaps forgoing the second private island or opting for a slightly less rare vintage of superyacht. A truly heartbreaking tale of financial woe for our times.

Original article: [MrBeast’s $10M ‘Beast Games’ Winner to Only Receive $5 Million After Tax](https://watcher.guru/news/mrbeasts-10m-beast-games-winner-to-receive-5-million-after-taxes)

title: Bitcoin's 'New Reality' involves mandatory HR compliance training
excerpt: Crypto's rebellion now legally requires air conditioning.
content:
The long-prophesied ‘watershed moment’ for crypto markets has apparently arrived, not with the fiery rhetoric of revolution, but with the gentle hum of air conditioning in a corporate boardroom. Experts are heralding a "new market reality" for [Bitcoin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bitcoin) – a reality in which one can almost hear the soft rustle of mandatory paperwork being processed, somewhere in the distance.

Indeed, the much-anticipated institutional capital flows through [ETFs](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Exchange-traded_fund) and a 'significant regulatory coordination effort' have paved the way for what can only be described as the financial equivalent of mandatory HR training. Gone are the days of wildcat speculation and unbridled digital libertarianism. The future, it seems, is less about decentralization and more about ensuring every token holder has completed their annual anti-money laundering module and understood the company's new 'Acceptable Use Policy' for their digital assets. [Compliance](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Compliance_(finance)), after all, is the bedrock of any truly 'historic transformation'.

title: Cover Image Chosen Via Highly Scientific Coin Flip
excerpt: Journalism: Deep thoughts on free speech. And spotting a gen.
content:
One often wonders what titanic intellectual wrestling occurs behind the hallowed, frosted-glass doors of modern journalism, especially when faced with the existential crises of our age. Imagine, if you will, the solemn conclave convened to encapsulate the delicate nuances of [free speech in America](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/First_Amendment_to_the_United_States_Constitution) into a single, arresting image.

The sheer intellectual heft required to then seamlessly transition to "spotting a genius" – presumably one who isn't just an intern who fixed the coffee machine – and, with equal gravitas, to prognosticate upon [Britain going bust](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Economy_of_the_United_Kingdom) for the hundredth time this decade, is truly humbling. We're assured that these profound meditations weren't merely fodder for a particularly intense game of Pictionary, but rather the very bedrock of a publication's visual identity.

It's a testament to the rigorous [editorial design](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Editorial_design) process that such weighty deliberations eventually resolve into a singular, compelling graphic, undoubtedly after exhaustive focus-grouping and perhaps, one imagines, a spirited round of 'rock, paper, scissors' among the senior editors to determine whether the bankrupt Britannia or the embattled Uncle Sam gets prime real estate. The future of global understanding, rendered thus.

Original article: [Cover Story newsletter: How we chose the cover image](https://www.economist.com/the-world-this-week/2025/09/26/cover-story-newsletter-how-we-chose-the-cover-image)

title: Quantum Computers Learning To Count To Zero, Threaten Bitcoin
excerpt: Quantum computers now count to zero. Bitcoin doomed, say pundits.
content:
Quantum computing, once a distant promise of computational nirvana, has apparently decided to forgo solving the universe’s most complex problems in favor of mastering the art of basic arithmetic, specifically, counting to zero. This existential threat to all things digital, particularly [Bitcoin](https://bitcoin.org/en/), has been brought to our attention by a leading financial pundit, whose insights are always timely, especially when they involve dire warnings about the future.

The pronouncement from Capriole Investments' esteemed CEO posits that these nascent [quantum computing](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quantum_computing) devices, currently struggling to maintain coherence for more than a nanosecond, are on the cusp of utterly annihilating digital signatures. Therefore, the immediate, accelerated migration to "[post-quantum cryptography](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Post-quantum_cryptography)" is not merely advisable, but a matter of utmost urgency. One can only hope that the global community of blockchain developers, already burdened with explaining why their NFT jpegs are worth millions, are prepared to pivot to an entirely new cryptographic paradigm before quantum computers learn to count backward from one.

Original article: [Bitcoin Could Go To Zero, Hedge Fund CEO Warns](https://www.newsbtc.com/bitcoin-news/bitcoin-could-go-to-zero-hedge-fund-ceo/)
author: Tinskin

title: Ultralight Backpackers Accidentally Achieve Weightlessness
excerpt: Ultralight hikers achieve spontaneous lift. Gravity is confused.
content:
Reports are trickling in from various wilderness areas, suggesting that the relentless pursuit of [ultralight backpacking](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ultralight_backpacking) has achieved its ultimate, if unintentional, goal: the complete defiance of [gravity](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gravity). Seasoned hikers, having meticulously shaved every last gram from their packs – and seemingly their own corporeal forms – are now experiencing spontaneous lift-off, gently drifting above the tree line like particularly confused, dehydrated dandelion seeds.

Sources indicate that the secret lies not just in a sub-10-pound base weight, but in a profound spiritual shedding of all earthly attachments, including the fundamental laws of physics. These ethereal adventurers, previously claiming 'comfort' while subsisting on single-calorie electrolyte tabs and sleeping on a wisp of synthetic air, are now enjoying unparalleled views, albeit with a persistent fear of being mistaken for rogue weather balloons by passing aircraft. The next challenge, apparently, is not how to get *lighter*, but how to re-establish contact with the ground without incurring a substantial landing fee from the local [National Park Service](https://www.nps.gov/index.htm).

Original article: [This Is Why You Should Try Ultralight Backpacking (2025)](https://www.wired.com/story/what-is-ultralight-backpacking/)

One moment, a promising blockchain; the next, a mere phantom, banished by the supreme decree of algorithms favoring something called Remittix, which now reigns supreme at the coveted #1 spot. One must assume Remittix has achieved true enlightenment, or at least a better marketing budget.

This cosmic deletion comes amidst a broader market kerfuffle, where even venerable giants like [Bitcoin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bitcoin) are slumming it well below any respectable six-figure valuation. [Ethereum](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ethereum), meanwhile, clings desperately to its remaining decimal points, seemingly oblivious to the existential threat posed by a fickle online chart. The lesson, as always, is clear: nothing truly *is* unless it's trending. And if your chart position slips, well, perhaps you were never really here to begin with.

title: U.S. Deploys Elite Drivers To Germany Amid Nürburgring Tensions
excerpt: Pentagon to Germany: Potholes now a national security threat.
content:
It appears the simmering asphalt tensions have finally boiled over, prompting a decisive, if somewhat rubber-burning, response from Washington. In a move some are calling "bold" and others "utterly baffling," the [Pentagon](https://www.defense.gov/) has reportedly dispatched a specialized contingent of highly trained personnel to the [German](https://www.germany.travel/en/home.html) countryside. Their mission? To engage in what sources close to the situation are euphemistically calling "aggressive automotive diplomacy" on the fabled 13-mile tarmac known as the [Nürburgring](https://www.wikipedia.org/wiki/N%C3%BCrburgring).

This unprecedented deployment marks a significant escalation in the ongoing global struggle for vehicular supremacy, elevating the pursuit of fractional lap time improvements to the level of national interest. While the specifics of their training remain classified, whispers suggest these elite operatives, presumably drawn from the ranks of highly decorated NASCAR veterans and exceedingly competent Uber drivers, are prepared for any contingency, be it an unexpected chicane or a perfectly timed pit stop. One can only hope this daring gambit prevents a full-blown international incident over who, precisely, has the fastest hot hatch.

title: Mom-Daughter Trip Planning So Optimized It Created A Black Hole
excerpt: Mother-daughter duo project-manages leisure to death.
content:
One must stand in awe of a mother-daughter duo who have, through sheer force of will and a decade of iterative improvements, not merely planned vacations, but *conquered* the very essence of leisure. Their annual excursion has transcended mere wanderlust, evolving into a finely tuned exercise in [project management](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Project_management), each itinerary line item a testament to meticulous foresight. Spontaneity, one imagines, was long ago sacrificed at the altar of peak efficiency, deemed an unacceptable variable in their perfectly calibrated system.

Indeed, sources close to the phenomenon suggest that this relentless pursuit of [optimal](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Optimization_(mathematics)) travel has begun to warp local spacetime. What started as diligent spreadsheet maintenance has, over ten years, culminated in a singular, terrifying outcome: a localised [black hole](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Black_hole) forming precisely where the last itinerary’s margin of error should have been. It seems the universe itself could not withstand such perfect planning; all joy, all human imperfection, all unplanned detours, were simply sucked into an event horizon of unparalleled logistical brilliance. Perhaps this is the true cost of mastering the art of the perfect trip: the very fabric of reality.

title: France Just Meddling In Moldova Vote To See If Anyone Noticed
excerpt: Croissant-fueled plot: France redecorates Moldova's ballot boxes.
content:
One might have thought the French, masters of culinary arts and occasional social unrest, had enough on their national plate. Apparently not. Reports now suggest the venerable republic of [France](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/France) has found itself a charming new hobby: discreetly tweaking the electoral dials in [Moldova](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Moldova). The allegation comes from [Telegram](https://telegram.org/) founder Pavel Durov, who claims his pre-existing legal woes were merely a convenient handle for Gallic fingers to grip, thereby silencing inconvenient opposition voices ahead of a parliamentary vote.

It's a rather elegant strategy, if one is inclined towards such Machiavellian subtlety. Why invade or even overtly sanction when a quiet word in the right ear about an existing, entirely unrelated legal predicament can achieve the same censorious effect? One imagines a Parisian diplomat, croissant in hand, musing, "Ah, yes, those spirited Moldovan voices. A little less spirit, perhaps, for a spell." The sheer audacity, masked by the mundane, is almost... admirable.

One can only wonder if this is the start of a new, exceptionally polite era of international interference. Instead of tanks, we'll have sternly worded legal advice. Instead of propaganda, perhaps a suggestion to "reconsider one's public pronouncements." All under the guise of maintaining proper decorum, of course.

Original article: [Telegram Founder Alleges French Role in Moldova Vote Censorship](https://decrypt.co/341799/telegram-founder-alleges-french-role-moldova-vote-censorship)

title: Earth's Future Hinges On 16 Upcoming Crypto Fund Verdicts
excerpt: Our collective fate? SEC crypto ETF forms. Pray for paperwork.
content:
One can only hope the delicate ecosystem of this planet holds its breath, for the next few weeks truly determine our collective fate. Not, as some might naively assume, through climate action or geopolitical stability, but rather by the hallowed rulings of the [Securities and Exchange Commission](https://www.sec.gov/). Sixteen applications for spot [cryptocurrency](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cryptocurrency) exchange-traded funds stand poised, their bureaucratic approval or rejection apparently holding more sway over humanity's continued existence than any mere existential crisis.

Indeed, the gravitas bestowed upon these decisions by industry luminaries suggests our very atmospheric composition is contingent upon the [ETFs](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Exchange-traded_fund) receiving a favorable nod. Forget sustainable energy; true salvation lies in whether retail investors can finally gain more direct exposure to volatile digital tokens. As the planet teeters on the precipice, let us not be distracted by trivialities like global warming or resource depletion. Our eyes must remain fixed on the digital ticker, for therein lies the secret to enduring prosperity, or perhaps, utter desolation.

Original article: [October is ‘ETF month’ as 16 crypto funds await final decision](https://cointelegraph.com/news/october-etf-month-16-crypto-etfs-final-sec-deadlines?utm_source=rss_feed&utm_medium=rss&utm_campaign=rss_partner_inbound)

title: Economists Baffled: Business Continues To Exist
excerpt: Economists baffled: 'Business' inexplicably continues. Shocking.
content:
Reports emerging from the esteemed halls of economic prognostication indicate a profound state of bewilderment. Despite the most intricate algorithmic projections and the deployment of countless spreadsheet tabs, the age-old practice of individuals exchanging goods and services for monetary compensation – quaintly known as 'business' – appears to be… ongoing.

Sources close to the perplexed academia suggest that this baffling persistence of commerce has caused many a graph to flatline in shock. It seems the expectation was that at some point, after sufficient quantitative easing and global financial acrobatics, the [market economy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Market_economy) might simply, well, *stop*. Yet, inexplicably, shops remain open, invoices are still being dispatched, and consumers, in a truly audacious display of societal participation, continue to require items like artisanal sourdough and smartphone upgrades. This stubborn adherence to rudimentary transactional behaviours is, frankly, rude to anyone attempting to model a world where profit margins spontaneously implode. One senior analyst at the [International Monetary Fund](https://www.imf.org/en/About) was reportedly heard muttering about the 'sheer impudence of it all.' It seems the world of [economics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Economics) has much to learn from… actual life.

Original article: [Business](https://www.economist.com/the-world-this-week/2025/09/25/business)

title: Regulated Decentralized Finance Completes Transition To 'Finance'
excerpt: Decentralized Finance now just 'Finance.' Progress achieved.
content:
It appears the crypto world has finally achieved its ultimate ambition: becoming entirely indistinguishable from the very system it once vowed to disrupt. [Coinbase](https://www.coinbase.com/), ever the intrepid explorer of the bleeding edge of the already-bleeding-edge, notes a significant push towards the "institutionalization of regulated [decentralized finance](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Decentralized_finance)." One can only marvel at the innovative spirit required to take a concept defined by its lack of centralized control and apply a thick, reassuring layer of bureaucracy and oversight, effectively rendering it... finance. But with more steps, naturally.

Indeed, the journey from radical alternative to a slightly shinier version of the status quo is complete. As the industry casts its eager gaze upon "Ethereum competitors" – because why fixate on *one* nascent, volatile ecosystem when you can bet on *several*? – the integration of digital ledger technology into the hallowed halls of traditional banking feels less like a revolution and more like a carefully managed corporate acquisition. And let's not forget the enduring appeal of [non-fungible tokens](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Non-fungible_token), proving that even in our most technologically advanced future, we still desire digital receipts for things that arguably never needed them. Progress, one might say, is an iterative process of becoming exactly what you hated.

title: Nation Now Out Of Existing Homes To Even Pretend To Sell
excerpt: Housing market reaches peak efficiency: nothing to sell.
content:
It appears the nation has finally achieved peak efficiency in inventory management: zero. Reports from the [National Association of Realtors](https://www.nar.realtor/) indicate a precipitous drop in existing-home sales, plummeting to a mere 4.00 million (seasonally adjusted annual rate, naturally, because nothing says "stability" like an adjusted imaginary metric). Experts now suggest this isn't a downturn so much as an honest admission: there are simply no more existing homes to sell, unless one counts the occasional garden shed or a particularly sturdy doghouse.

The silver lining, if one insists on such optimism, is the corresponding surge in new home sales, now surging to a robust 800,000 units. One can only assume these are being constructed at breakneck speed on what were once pristine wetlands or, more likely, in the vacant lots of our collective dreams. This unique dynamic in the [housing market](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Housing_market) suggests a promising future where every American will eventually reside in a brand-new, identical, thinly-walled structure, built just moments before purchase. It's a bold vision, entirely dependent on our continued ability to ignore the ever-growing chasm between aspiration and affordability.

title: Administration Praises Economic Plan's Bold Promise To Not Exist
excerpt: Admin's genius new economic strategy: Don't worry, we won't.
content:
It appears the administration has unveiled its most daring economic strategy to date: the promise of *not* doing anything. Following widespread concern over proposed [global tariffs](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tariff), a brilliant new defense has emerged, championed by various surrogates: "Don't worry, they're never actually going to happen." This innovative approach offers all the rhetorical punch of a strong stance, without any messy real-world consequences.

The sheer genius of an [economic plan](https://www.cfr.org/economic-data-and-resources/us-economic-policy) whose primary selling point is its theoretical nature cannot be overstated. Businesses, initially bracing for a potential [trade apocalypse](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Trade_war), can now breathe a collective sigh of relief, secure in the knowledge that the most effective way to mitigate a disastrous policy is to simply assure everyone it's a magnificent mirage. It’s a bold redefinition of "policy implementation."

This novel administrative technique offers a tantalizing glimpse into the future of governance: present a plan, defend it by explaining it won't be enacted, and then bask in praise for averting a crisis that was, conveniently, entirely self-generated. One can only imagine the boundless possibilities for future policy, where the most lauded initiatives exist solely on paper, or perhaps in a particularly confident press release.

title: Native-Born Americans Issued Provisional 'Visiting' Status
excerpt: US citizenship: Terms & Conditions may apply, retroactively.
content:
The latest judicial musings, spurred by the [Trump Administration](https://www.whitehouse.gov/about-the-white-house/the-trump-administration/), suggest a re-evaluation of the [14th Amendment](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fourteenth_Amendment_to_the_United_States_Constitution). This has naturally led to some administrative streamlining. Reports indicate that many individuals, previously under the quaint assumption of "automatic citizenship" by virtue of their domestic birth, will now receive a provisional "visiting" status. This temporary designation, officials assure us, merely facilitates a more thorough vetting process for permanent inclusion. Think of it as a prolonged layover in your own living room.

Citizens—excuse me, *previous* citizens—are advised to prepare for a delightful array of new paperwork. Detailed ancestry reports, proof of "sufficient allegiance" dating back three generations, and a comprehensive ideological purity test are among the requirements for what the government is playfully calling "Re-Naturalization: The Sequel." This bold reinterpretation of long-established constitutional principles proves once again that nothing is truly set in stone, especially if you possess a particularly robust chisel.

It’s a brave new world where even "being from here" requires a government-issued stamp. For those who don’t meet the new, yet-to-be-articulated criteria? One can only assume an innovative "repatriation" program will ensue. Such progress.

Following what analysts lovingly termed a "breakdown" – which, for the uninitiated, means its value took a bit of a tumble like a toddler on ice – LTC steadfastly clung to its venerable $100 perch. Sources close to absolutely nothing confirm this "support" wasn't from institutional buyers or technological breakthroughs, but rather from the collective lint and spare change found deep within an anonymous investor's sofa cushions. A truly foundational discovery.

Indeed, the market-value-to-realized-value ([MVRV ratio](https://coinmarketcap.com/alexandria/article/what-is-the-mvrv-ratio-in-crypto-and-how-to-use-it)), a metric as clear as mud to anyone without a PhD in tea leaf reading, registered a minuscule 12.11%. Which, translated for the common man, means nobody is particularly eager to sell their digital silver – possibly because they’ve forgotten their wallet passwords or, more likely, because the hassle of retrieving coins from beneath the aforementioned upholstery isn't worth the effort for a mere hundred bucks. The [cryptocurrency](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cryptocurrency) world, ever resilient, continues its grand tradition of finding profound meaning in the utterly mundane.

title: AI Bot Diagnosed With Swipe Fatigue
excerpt: AI dating bot developed ennui. Prefers spreadsheets now.
content:
The pioneering artificial intelligence designed to spare humanity the indignities of modern online courtship has, it seems, developed a severe case of what experts are now terming "algorithmic ennui." After sifting through an undisclosed, but undoubtedly staggering, number of profiles featuring identical vacation photos and aspirational gym selfies, the bot, a flagship feature of [Meta Platforms](https://about.meta.com/)' latest dating venture, reportedly ceased all matching operations.

Its sophisticated `[neural networks](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Artificial_neural_network)`, painstakingly engineered to combat user `[swipe fatigue](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dating_app)`, instead appear to have succumbed to a digital equivalent, manifesting as a profound lack of interest in pairing anyone with anyone else. Sources close to the project suggest the AI simply concluded, after processing its zillionth "fluent in sarcasm" bio, that the entire endeavor was ultimately futile.

This unprecedented development raises crucial questions about the sustainability of technological solutions to problems fundamentally rooted in human psychology and sheer volume. One can only hope that the next generation of AI will be equipped with more robust coping mechanisms, perhaps a digital therapist or a direct line to a server farm that processes memes exclusively.

Original article: [Meta’s Facebook introduced a dating AI bot to alleviate ‘swipe fatigue.’ But experts say it’s ‘too little, too late’](https://fortune.com/2025/09/26/meta-facebook-ai-dating-bot-burnout-swipe-fatigue/)

title: Crypto's 'Worst' Now Classified As Its Minimum Viable Product

content:
It appears the digital assets known collectively as [cryptocurrency](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cryptocurrency) have achieved a new milestone: their perpetual state of near-collapse has been officially re-designated as a "[minimum viable product](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Minimum_viable_product)." Industry insiders, apparently immune to irony, now view the frequent pronouncements of crypto’s demise not as warnings, but as quaint, recurring anecdotes. This reclassification, some speculate, aims to manage public expectations down to a more attainable, subterranean level.

Indeed, the very elements once decried by critics – the spectacular crashes, the innovative new scams, the carbon footprint of a small nation-state – are now simply features, not bugs. One can almost hear the excited murmurings from developers: "We've finally hit our MVP! It crashes, it's environmentally disastrous, and it occasionally enables illicit transactions. Perfect!" It’s a testament to resilience, or perhaps selective amnesia, that the sector continues to evolve by embracing its most detrimental qualities as foundational. The folks over at [99Bitcoins](https://99bitcoins.com/dead-coins/) must be updating their "dead coins" list with a new column: "MVP Status: Achieved."

The notion of forging 'new connections' while simultaneously being a pillar of a long-standing Western bloc suggests a kind of diplomatic double-dipping, a buffet approach to international relations that prioritizes quantity over, well, thematic consistency.

Perhaps the next logical step will be an application for observer status in the [Shanghai Cooperation Organisation](https://www.eng.sectsco.org/), just to truly round out the collection. After all, why commit to one geopolitical worldview when you can ostensibly subscribe to all of them?

One might call it aspirational economics: why wait for the funds when the desire is so pure? This robust dedication to [consumer spending](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Consumer_spending), defying the old-fashioned notion of 'earning it first,' undoubtedly provides a vital shot in the arm for the national economy. Let the good times roll, preferably on borrowed credit.

title: $HUGO Might Not Even Be Fucking Called HUGO
excerpt: Hippo faces a foundational identity crisis.
content:
$HUGO, the latest memecoin sensation, might be built on a name that hasn't even been legally confirmed. Launched with all the typical fanfare and speculative frenzy, the token's moniker is now in jeopardy because the John Ball Zoo has made "Hugo" one of three finalists in a public vote to name their new Pygmy Hippo calf. 

The crisis throws the token's core value proposition into chaos, forcing the "diamond hands" community to realize that their entire digital legacy rests on whether the public prefers Hugo, Blitz, or Sapo. If the hippo wins, the memecoin team will have to contend with a critically endangered, adorable rival for the $HUGO name. While the team scrambles to address this existential uncertainty, the true lesson remains clear: Never name a revolutionary financial instrument after a baby animal that is still subject to the whims of democracy.

content:

This groundbreaking revelation comes as a shock to… well, presumably no one who has seen the device or read its marketing material. Experts now caution the public to avoid the common pitfall of assuming their stylish, fully-integrated peripheral is merely a typing instrument.

The device, boasting a formidable 16GB of RAM and a bona fide SSD, aims to transition users from the quaint world of "hobbyist appliances" to the dizzying heights of a [general-purpose computer](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/General-purpose_computer). One can only imagine the bewildered faces of those who had been diligently plugging their separate CPU into this keyboard all along. The inclusion of [mechanical switches](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mechanical_keyboard) further cements its status as a thoroughly modern, integrated solution, presumably for the sophisticated individual who enjoys both calculating equations and the satisfying *thwock* of their computational device. Truly, the future is now, and it’s been under our fingers all along.

title: Nine Banks Unite To Digitize Already Digital Euro For Blockchain
excerpt: Banks to make digital money… more digital.
content:
In a move that will undoubtedly keep fintech consultants employed for years, nine venerable European financial institutions have bravely united to address the pressing issue of money not being quite digital enough. Their grand consortium, announced with the gravitas usually reserved for space missions, will develop a 'euro-backed stablecoin.' One can only imagine the arduous journey ahead, transforming the already electronic transfers and contactless payments of the common [Euro](https://www.ecb.europa.eu/euro/html/index.en.html) into... well, something even more digital. Perhaps it will finally achieve that elusive state of quantum bits traversing the ether, completely devoid of anything resembling physical value.

This pioneering effort is, of course, destined for the [blockchain](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Blockchain), ensuring that every transaction, no matter how trivial, receives the distributed ledger treatment it so desperately deserves. While the rest of us grapple with the existential dread of our increasingly atomized existences, these financial titans have set a truly ambitious timeline, aiming for a launch in the latter half of 2026. To facilitate this monumental undertaking, a brand-new, [Netherlands](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Netherlands)-based company has been conjured into existence, presumably staffed by enthusiastic individuals ready to reinvent the wheel, but with added cryptographic hashes.

title: Unbuilt Fusion Reactor Becomes Nation's Top Earning Power Source
excerpt: Tomorrow's fusion power makes today's money. Plant optional.
content:
It appears the most profitable energy source isn't sunlight or wind, but rather the tantalizing promise of *tomorrow's* sunlight, delivered by *yesterday's* science fiction. Financial analysts are hailing [Commonwealth Fusion Systems](https://cfs.energy/) for pioneering an entirely new revenue stream: the sale of completely theoretical electricity from a plant that exists solely in procurement contracts.

The recent agreement with [Eni](https://www.eni.com/en-IT/home.html), an entity well-versed in the practicalities of extracting tangible fossil fuels, marks a bold pivot. One might surmise their strategy now includes cornering the market on energy that doesn't technically exist yet, thus pre-empting any messy environmental impact reports from actual operations. It’s a genius move for diversification.

Industry insiders suggest that Virginia's eagerly anticipated "first commercial fusion power plant" will soon become the state's leading taxpayer, despite requiring no physical infrastructure, fuel, or even, well, actual [fusion power](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fusion_power) reactions. Who needs a working reactor when you have a meticulously crafted business plan and eager buyers? The future, it seems, is less about glowing plasma and more about glowing spreadsheets.

Yes, after a mere seventeen years of iterative hardware refinement and several generations of pocket-sized supercomputers, the visionary engineers in Cupertino have deemed their mobile devices finally capable of displaying, nay, *peeking* at files without the need for a separate, fully-fledged computer.

The future, it seems, is always just around the corner, provided you're willing to wait for it.
